JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, DECEMBER 10, 1965

70TH YEAR

Macaulay To Retire After 30 Years

Officials Issue Rights Report
Macaulay, Hop
V. P., To Retire
At End of Year
P. Stewart Macaulay, executive vice president of The Johns
Hopkins University, will retire
from his position at the end of
this academic year on June 30,
1966, it was announced today by
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, University President.
Mr. Macaulay has been a
senior officer of the University
since 1936, though his affiliation
began even earlier as a student.
Doctor Eisenhower said: "Mr.
Macaulay has made known to
me his desire to retire at the
Close of this academic year for
reasons of health and the Board
of Trustees and I have reluctantly agreed. Mr. Macaulay has
made immeasureable contributions to The Johns Hopkins
University during his nearly
three decades of service. He has
been a continuing and important
Officer in the administration of
four Johns Hopkins presidents
and has fulfilled vital functions
Involving the institution's fiscal

By PETER KOPER
A resolution concerning the
attempted flag lowering at Ft.
McHenry by a group of Hopkins
students last May, was passed
by the Maryland Department, of
the Veterans of Foreign Wars on
November 14. The resolution
calls for a re-examination of the
State Department Foreign 'Student Exchange Program in the
light of the alleged participations in the action by three Hopkins foreign students.
Copies of the document have
been sent by the V.F.W. office
in Baltimore to several Maryland General Assembly members
and the eight Maryland congressmen. Other copies were distributed to the press, and radio
and television stations.
The Resolution
The resolution was adapted
unanimously by the Council of
Administration of the V.P.W.,
composed of 25 District Commanders alter a report was submitted by an investigating committee.

Moody To Speak
On Church at Y
The Levering Hall YMCA will
sponsor several activities this
week. The program starts with
the Christmas mixer tonight and
eontinues through the fourth
Jeffrey lecture Monday night,
the YMCA Annual Bonanza
Christmas Sale Wednesday afternoon, and the traditional "Y"
Wednesday
party
Christmas
night.
Rev. Howard Moody, Pastor of
the Judson Memorial Church in
Greenwich Village. New York,
will deliver the fourth in this
year's Elmer B. Jeffrey Lecture
Series, December 13 at 4.00 p.m.
In Levering Hall He will speak
on the "Marks of the New Reformation: The Role of the
Church in a Secular Society."
According to John Connally,
Seminary Intern of the levering
Hall YMCA, "Rev. Moody has
been a catalytic figure in New
York City's politics, arts, and
social reform movements." He is
co-chairman of the N. Y. Civil
Liberties Union, on the Board of
Directors of the N. Y. NAACP,
author of The Fourth Man, and
Was chairman of the Democrats
tor Lindsay.
Other Speakers
This lecture series is conducted
hi order to bring speakers to
Hopkins pertaining to current
eontroversies in religious and
social fields. The program is
Planned by the staff of Levering

Hall with the approval of the
Baltimore Metropolitan YMCA
Jeffrey Lecture Committee. Other
speakers scheduled for this academic year include: Bayard
Rustin, Executive Director of the
A. Phillip Randolph Institute;
Dr. Molford Sibley, political
scientist from the University of
Minnesota; and Eugene Carson
Blake, Head of the United Presbyterian Church.
The "Y" will hold its annual
Bonanza Christmas Sale December 15 from 10.00 a.m. to 5.00
pm in the Great Hall of Levering
Hall In addition to auctioning
off the "Y's" lost and found articles, the staff plans many sur-.
prise items, dinners, tickets to
the Gaiety, tutoring services of
professors, and others. The receipts, which will range from five
cents to fifty dollars for a single
item, go toward making up the
"Y's" deficit.
Christmas Party
Following the step sing Wednesday night, the "Y" will be the
host for its annual Christmas
party. Everyone in the Hopkins
community, members and nonmembers, is invited. Free refreshments and amusements will
be provided.
The "Y's" Christmas mixer
will be held tonight in Levering Hall. The "Manchesters",
an eight piece rock and roll
combo will provide the music.

In response to the evolutionary
trends of the Civil Rights movement locally and nationally,
Johns Hopkins University officials have issued a report entitled, "Human Rights at the
Johns Hopkins University."

The report pledges the University to "continuation of its
efforts" in endeavoring to carry-:ing through "non-discrimination" at all levels, with an eye
toward incorporating practical
problems in implementing their
policy. It proclaimed as a basis
for its policy that discrimination
"is especially repugnant in a
university environment for the
accomplishment of the university's central mission of education
and research."
One administrator noted that
this report was a part of a response to the "spirit of change"
within the civil rights movement. The greater concern for
public declaration of support and
action for civil rights programs
has become the "thing to do;"
prior to this changed tenor of
civil rights, the report said that
"the aim of the University was
to be a model of non-discrimination, but to do it quietly."
Student Action
Increased action toward a
more liberal stand began at Hopkins on the part of students four
years ago with the formation of
the Basic Freedoms Committee.

Fraternity discrimination came

Two representatives of the
University Heights Improvement
Association spoke to the Interfraternity Council at their meeting Friday, December 3, in Levering Hall. The representatives,
Milton Schlenger and W. R.
Walker, warned the fraternities
that they must keep their properties neat.
Schlenger stated that the association was involved in a drive
to prevent the deterioration of
the University Heights area,
which extends from University
Parkway to 25th St. and from
Maryland to Guilford Ayes. He
told the fraternities that they
must clean up the front of their
houses. He said that the association would not allow trash on
the lawns in the neighborhood.
In response to a question by
Henry Hocherman, Schlenger
added that this group was to re-

ceive a grant for the Federal Urban Renewal Program and that
this would enable them to fOrce
compliance.
No Ball Playing
The Association also demanded that there be no more ball
playing on Charles, St. Paul, and
Calvert Sts. during the weekend.
Mr. Schlenger warned that contrary to prior policy, any Hopkins student picked up by the
police would be taken into court,
booked, and given a record. Both
Mr. Walker and Mr. Schlenger
emphasized that if the fraternities acted like gentlemen, in the
Hopkins tradition, there would
be no problem. The houses at
29th and Calvert and at Charles
and 29th were singled out as in
need of improvement.

he was named provost. In 1959
he was appointed executive vice

Mr. Macaulay has served as
Trustee from 1946 to 1965 of Associated Universities, Inc.. an
organization of major American
universities which operate the
Brookhaven National Laboratory. During this period he
served as a member of the executive committee !or four separate
two-year terms and was chairman of the board in 1952-53.
He also served In 1959-60 as
Trustee of the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research,
a similar inter-University research agency. From 1962 to
1964 he Was a Trustee of the
Commission on Governmental
Efficiency and Economy, Inc.
Mr. Macaulay is a member of
Phi Gamma Delta and the
Johns Hopkins Club. He is married to the former Elizabeth
Galloway and they reside at 305
Thornhill Road, Baltimore. They
have two children, Mrs. Cecil H.
Hull, and Roes Galloway.

Reaction
The Basic Freedoms Committee, which has expanded to a
membership of 16 and is preparing a set of proposals for
further action in recruiting Negro personnel on all levels of the
University, met Tuesday night to
discuss the University report.
The committee reacted generally
in an amused manner. They felt
that while the report was a first
step at some administration-student communication, the report
was ineffectual and unsympathetic to their programs of action.

'65 Act Provides
Grants to Needy
Johns Hopkins will participate
bi the Higher Education Act of
1965 program, according to the
Director of Financial Aid, James
L. Bowman. The program calls
for assistance to undergraduates
Who come from families where
Income is less than $5,000.
"The purpose of these grants",
Mr. Bowman stated, "is to reach
those potential students who are
not and can not go on to higher
education because of financial
need." Mr. Bowman went on to
say that, the extent of Hopkins'
participation may not be heavy
at first because few students here
now come from families where
Income is less than $5,000.
Grants from $200 to $800 will
be given under the act, and must
be watched by other sources,
either public or private. Mr.
Bowman feels that this will
make It possible for colleges to
go out and recruit students with
ability from lower income areas
and indeed, enable Hopkins to
have the funds to offer students
from low income families a
chance to come here. The grants
will be given through the colleges.

The perspective of students is subject to limitations,
the most important of which is his repugnance to perspective. Their cause, most particular, the cause of
human rights, has only short run objectives, while any
institution that bears the attack of their righteous demands, is committed to carrying out a long run, more
abstract plan.
The officials of the institutions, on the other hand,
are not themselves free from limitations, for commitment to a long run objective can be even more short
sighted. The long run obligation can often, if pursued
by unenlightened persons be a most inflexible policy.
Any deviation from the long run, is discarded, often
without (Inc consideration, as unethical and disadvantageous.
The issue of discrimination at Hopkins has obviously shown how difficult it is to negotiate between the
long run and the short run. In this case it has outlined
a peculiar phenomenon: the student-administration gap.
The gap is inevitable and regrettable. It is inevitable
because the official wishes, quite rightly to channel as
much intellectual and productive capital into the university as possible in order to increase its diversity, complexity, industry and external prestige.
The students, on the other hand wish for a more
intimate, less industrial community. The administration
sets their long run objective to be the augmenting of
Hopkins' capacity to instruct and research. Short Run
objectives aspire to non-discrimination on all levels;
and this often requires that this capacity not be maintained at peak efficiency.
But the two poles are not irreconcilable. The gap
can be mended in spots. The administration must not
be above political negotiation despite their lofty longrun purpose; and in order to deal with the issue of
civil rights in its substance and procedure, they must
have a reservoir of flexibility and must not be too old
to use U.
The students, on the other hand, must realize that
they are dealing in short run programs despite the universality of their cause. The administrators are not
therefore standing in the way of "the great wind of
change toward truth" but a merely posing practical
problems to an awkward set of idealistic proposals. They
must be treated at least as humanely as the Negroes.

Apology
The photograph of the Santa Claus that appeared

on the real Santa Claus. We apologize for the misuse of

White, "Morie" Pattern and Reliefs and Construction.
Color Image paintings depend
on original and stunning color
aombinations anc.! composition.
Shapes are limited to simple
units so that the all important
color elements of the painting
are given the greatest freedom
to dominate.
In an Invisible Painting the
difference betweea tone and color within a canvas is so slight
that at first it appears homogeneous. The eye must adjust to
gradually perceive the depth of
what is, initially, an invisible
distinction.
The creators of Optical Paintings realize the discrepencies between physical fact and psychic
effect. They have concluded that
no color or shape haa an individual identity that cannot be
changed or altered by the elements that surround it.
If an artist is interested In
Causing the activation of vision

in the simplest manner he may
choose to work with Black and
White. Black and White provides a medium where sequential
changes in the spacing of shapes
cause to merge granting impressions of pulseatian and intensity.
Often the eye is presented with
such amazing visual energy that
it hallucinates color.
Moire Patterns are created by
calendering two rolls of silk face
to face placing one set of lines
on another in an off-parallel relationship. Reliefs and Construction are paintings, doubled
or squared.
Optical Art has begun a new
phase in art but brings with it
a host of new questions. William
Seitz, curator of the Museum of
Modern Art asks; "Can such
works, that refer to nothing outside themselves, replace with
psychic effectiveness the content
that has been abandoned?"
Clearly the answer lies not only
in a responsive eye but in a responsive mind as well.

MATHEMATICIANS
Technical representatives
of The MITRE Corporation
will be conducting interviews
on campus
January 6. 1966
MITRE is chief technical advisor and systems engineer to the Air
Force Electronic Systems Division of the Air Force Systems
Command. In this capacity, we design and develop such global,
computer-based systems as the NORAD Combat Operations
Center and the Back-Up Interceptor Control System. Other commitments: development of a future air traffic control system and
supporting the Defense Communications Agency in the development of the National Military Command System;
For the young systems engineer, this is uniquely rewarding work.
You associate with the top men in your field. You work in an
atmosphere that allows you to extend your capabilities professionally and academically.
At MITRE, men trained in single disciplines are encouraged to
grow beyond their original fields of interest. Systems designers
learn to work from an increasingly broad base.
You may work in such diverse areas as information theory, computer design, display techniques and propagation. You may
analyze. You may synthesize. You may deal with systems or individual components. At the highest levels, you may have to consider political, economic and social factors ... as well as the available and predictable technology.
Requirements: M.S., or Ph.D. in these disciplines — electronics,
physics, mathematics. MITRE is located in pleasant, suburban
Boston and also has facilities in Washington, D. C., Colorado
Springs and Florida. If an interview will be inconvenient, inquiries
may be directed in confidence to College Relations Coordinator,
The MITRE Corporation, Box 208, Dept. CN8, Bedford, Mass.

THE

MITRE

Prof. Refuses
Award Offer
Dr. Owen M. Phillips. a professor in the department of
mechanics at Hopkins, recently
refused to accept an award offered to him by the Maryland
Academy of Sciences. He refused a "distinguished young
scientist award" on the grounds
that the work of a scientist "is
reward enough in itself."
Dr. Phillips, a 34-year-old professor of Geophysical Mechanics
and a member of the faculty at
Hopkins since 1956, said that
he was "most grateful" for the
honor, but in a letter to the
academy wrote that he believed
"most sincerely that the value
of a scientist's work lies in his
contributions to our understanding of the world about us and in
the enlargement of this understanding in society and that the
doing of these things is reward
enough in itself. Though this
award may be intended as a recognition of my work in this
direction, I do not desire personal honors." Dr. Phillips then
requested to decline the award.
Dr. Phillips, a native of
Australia, came to Hopkins from
Cambridge University in England. He has published thirtyfive papers and is noted for his
work on waves and turbulence
in fluids.
Dr. George Benton, the chairman of the mechanics department, nominated Dr Phillips for
the award
without Phillip's
knowledge Dr Benton, corninentin.g on Dr Phillips action,
called Phillips "a tremendously
capable person" and a scientist
of "very broad gauge," and said
that the action was consistent
with Dr Phillips' modesty"

Insanity becomes their effective
means of compensation for the
deficiencies of the prison camp.
One character envisions his pet
chickens as children, one has
Illusions that his wife is with
him, and so on.
In the camp the usual stratification by military rank is broken
down — the artificial statuses
are destroyed and each character
is rewarded according to his
ability to survive. In one case
the characters steal from the
camp rations, but they are
caught by the provost and dismissed from their duties in
charge of the camp food.
King survives the ordeal best
of all—he is able to convert
goods into money and money
into food. He sells the jewelry
and possessions of the soldiers
to the Japanese for as much as
he can get, then keeps his commission. King has his followers
steal for him then sells the
goods to the Japanese, and as a
result the others starve while
King eats and dresses well. By
his own ingenuity he develops a
scheme to provide food for the
officers and money for himself.
King is the king of the camp—
his relationship with others is
based upon give and take. He
pays his followers for working
for him—and in return they do
favors for him. Only once does
King show any compassion for
his fellow prisoners—when he
acquires the sulfanimide to cure
Marlow from Gangreen.
When the war comes to an end
the old artificial order is reestablished and King is forced
to accept the usual commands
of his military superiors. He renounces his friendship with
Marlow and claims that it was
no more than the give and take

is ushered into the transport
truck leaving the camp for the

The Provost is King's chief

Is clearly not in the prison camp

Marlow, like King, is a tragic
figure in relation to his society—
he is an idealist, and is able to
express compassion for other
human beings. But it is impossible for him to succeed within
society, because of these characteristics.
Society turns King into
tragic hero, defines Marlow as
tragic being, and in its own
terms sets the provost. as the
model to emulate. All this, of
course, is not nice.

Swordsmen Win In Opener
By BARON WORMSER
Coach Dick Oles' varsity fencing team started to key on a
winning season early by opening
with a 14-13 scrimmage win over
Virginia Military Institute Friday.
Helping to turn the trick
against the Cadets were Walt
Rosett, Bernie Tauflk, and Steve
Mohr, all of whom pasted 2-0
*cores.
As usual the fencers will be
handicapped by graduation losses
and inexperience. The swordsmen have lost sabre ace Sherm
ireichman and North Atlantic
epee champ Bob Kirby but in the
eoach's words, "Rather than give
long sad story of whom we
iost I'd rather just work with
what we have here."
Each year the Jays have been
able to bounce right back as last
year they finished third in the
Middle Atlantic Conference and

r

captured the conference diadem
in 1963.
Epee Strong
The fencers' strong point figures to be epee, led by co-captain
Walt Rosett, who is defending
epee champion. Randy Perrine
will fence number two position
while the third slot is up for
grabs. Also figuring to be the
fencers' forte is foil spearheaded
by co-captain and third place
Mid-Atlantic medalist Jeremy
Lam. Backing up Lain will be
Larry Perkins and a yet to be
named third man.

and build up. Commenting on
the saber team, Coach Oles stated
that he hopes it will be able to
pick up on experience.

coach said that the Jays should
have a good crack at Lehigh,
Haverford Muhlenberg and Lafayette while Stevens and Temple
figure to be very close. As to
a win over Penn—"forget it."

now until January 7 when they

Hitchner Tough
Freshman coach Gary Barrette,
who scouted Swarthmore, reports
that it uses a 2-1-2 offense with
Hitchner playing a low post and
carrying the brunt of the offensive load. Barrette was high in
his praise of the 6-3 junior, saying that he drives very well for
a pivot man, has a fine jump
shot, and is very tough off the
boards.
Defensively, the Garnets are
basically a man-to-man club
which can fast break and handle
a wide open style of play very
well.
Wednesday's Action
In this respect, Swarthmore is
much like the Jays' opponent of
last Wednesday, Catholic University, one of the toughest adversaries on the Homewood club's
schedule. Catholic U. recently
pushed small college cage power
Mount St. Mary's into overtime
before bowing, which pretty
much tells the tale regarding its
capabilities.

its opening game encounter at

decision when Willy Schwenzfeier's jump shot with two seconds left in overtime went in
and out. With four players in
double figures, the Jays played
what Coach Henry Ciccarone

called "a tremendous game" and
were impressive in their hustle
and an aggressiveness at all
times.

its offense moving against a
tough Haverford zone defense.

in the first half, the Jays closed

70TH YEAR

Macaulay To Retire After 30 Years

Officials Issue Rights Report
Macaulay, Hop
V. P., To Retire
At End of Year
P. Stewart Macaulay, executive vice president of The Johns
Hopkins University, will retire
from his position at the end of
this academic year on June 30,
1966, it was announced today by
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, University President.
Mr. Macaulay has been a
senior officer of the University
since 1936, though his affiliation
began even earlier as a student.
Doctor Eisenhower said: "Mr.
Macaulay has made known to
me his desire to retire at the
Close of this academic year for
reasons of health and the Board
of Trustees and I have reluctantly agreed. Mr. Macaulay has
made immeasureable contributions to The Johns Hopkins
University during his nearly
three decades of service. He has
been a continuing and important
Officer in the administration of
four Johns Hopkins presidents
and has fulfilled vital functions
Involving the institution's fiscal

By PETER KOPER
A resolution concerning the
attempted flag lowering at Ft.
McHenry by a group of Hopkins
students last May, was passed
by the Maryland Department, of
the Veterans of Foreign Wars on
November 14. The resolution
calls for a re-examination of the
State Department Foreign 'Student Exchange Program in the
light of the alleged participations in the action by three Hopkins foreign students.
Copies of the document have
been sent by the V.F.W. office
in Baltimore to several Maryland General Assembly members
and the eight Maryland congressmen. Other copies were distributed to the press, and radio
and television stations.
The Resolution
The resolution was adapted
unanimously by the Council of
Administration of the V.P.W.,
composed of 25 District Commanders alter a report was submitted by an investigating committee.

Moody To Speak
On Church at Y
The Levering Hall YMCA will
sponsor several activities this
week. The program starts with
the Christmas mixer tonight and
eontinues through the fourth
Jeffrey lecture Monday night,
the YMCA Annual Bonanza
Christmas Sale Wednesday afternoon, and the traditional "Y"
Wednesday
party
Christmas
night.
Rev. Howard Moody, Pastor of
the Judson Memorial Church in
Greenwich Village. New York,
will deliver the fourth in this
year's Elmer B. Jeffrey Lecture
Series, December 13 at 4.00 p.m.
In Levering Hall He will speak
on the "Marks of the New Reformation: The Role of the
Church in a Secular Society."
According to John Connally,
Seminary Intern of the levering
Hall YMCA, "Rev. Moody has
been a catalytic figure in New
York City's politics, arts, and
social reform movements." He is
co-chairman of the N. Y. Civil
Liberties Union, on the Board of
Directors of the N. Y. NAACP,
author of The Fourth Man, and
Was chairman of the Democrats
tor Lindsay.
Other Speakers
This lecture series is conducted
hi order to bring speakers to
Hopkins pertaining to current
eontroversies in religious and
social fields. The program is
Planned by the staff of Levering

Hall with the approval of the
Baltimore Metropolitan YMCA
Jeffrey Lecture Committee. Other
speakers scheduled for this academic year include: Bayard
Rustin, Executive Director of the
A. Phillip Randolph Institute;
Dr. Molford Sibley, political
scientist from the University of
Minnesota; and Eugene Carson
Blake, Head of the United Presbyterian Church.
The "Y" will hold its annual
Bonanza Christmas Sale December 15 from 10.00 a.m. to 5.00
pm in the Great Hall of Levering
Hall In addition to auctioning
off the "Y's" lost and found articles, the staff plans many sur-.
prise items, dinners, tickets to
the Gaiety, tutoring services of
professors, and others. The receipts, which will range from five
cents to fifty dollars for a single
item, go toward making up the
"Y's" deficit.
Christmas Party
Following the step sing Wednesday night, the "Y" will be the
host for its annual Christmas
party. Everyone in the Hopkins
community, members and nonmembers, is invited. Free refreshments and amusements will
be provided.
The "Y's" Christmas mixer
will be held tonight in Levering Hall. The "Manchesters",
an eight piece rock and roll
combo will provide the music.

Johns Hopkins will participate
bi the Higher Education Act of
1965 program, according to the
Director of Financial Aid, James
L. Bowman. The program calls
for assistance to undergraduates
Who come from families where
Income is less than $5,000.
"The purpose of these grants",
Mr. Bowman stated, "is to reach
those potential students who are
not and can not go on to higher
education because of financial
need." Mr. Bowman went on to
say that, the extent of Hopkins'
participation may not be heavy
at first because few students here
now come from families where
Income is less than $5,000.
Grants from $200 to $800 will
be given under the act, and must
be watched by other sources,
either public or private. Mr.
Bowman feels that this will
make It possible for colleges to
go out and recruit students with
ability from lower income areas
and indeed, enable Hopkins to
have the funds to offer students
from low income families a
chance to come here. The grants
will be given through the colleges.

the most important of which is his repugnance to perspective. Their cause, most particular, the cause of
human rights, has only short run objectives, while any
institution that bears the attack of their righteous demands, is committed to carrying out a long run, more
abstract plan.
The officials of the institutions, on the other hand,
are not themselves free from limitations, for commitment to a long run objective can be even more short
sighted. The long run obligation can often, if pursued
by unenlightened persons be a most inflexible policy.
Any deviation from the long run, is discarded, often
without (Inc consideration, as unethical and disadvantageous.
The issue of discrimination at Hopkins has obviously shown how difficult it is to negotiate between the
long run and the short run. In this case it has outlined
a peculiar phenomenon: the student-administration gap.
The gap is inevitable and regrettable. It is inevitable
because the official wishes, quite rightly to channel as
much intellectual and productive capital into the university as possible in order to increase its diversity, complexity, industry and external prestige.
The students, on the other hand wish for a more
intimate, less industrial community. The administration
sets their long run objective to be the augmenting of
Hopkins' capacity to instruct and research. Short Run
objectives aspire to non-discrimination on all levels;
and this often requires that this capacity not be maintained at peak efficiency.
But the two poles are not irreconcilable. The gap
can be mended in spots. The administration must not
be above political negotiation despite their lofty longrun purpose; and in order to deal with the issue of
civil rights in its substance and procedure, they must
have a reservoir of flexibility and must not be too old
to use U.
The students, on the other hand, must realize that
they are dealing in short run programs despite the universality of their cause. The administrators are not
therefore standing in the way of "the great wind of
change toward truth" but a merely posing practical
problems to an awkward set of idealistic proposals. They
must be treated at least as humanely as the Negroes.

The photograph of the Santa Claus that appeared
in profile and front view in last week's issue of the
News-Letter was the product of the imagination of the
Johns Hopkins Magazine staff. It appeared in the NewsLetter unbeknownst to the editors of the magazine, and
was printed without permission or credit. We fear that
we gave the erroneous impression that the statue was
our own creation when in fact the Santa is not our
banta. He is the Johns Hopkins Magazine Santa.
We suggest that one turn to the December issue
et the J.H.U. Magazine for the unexpurgated low down
on the real Santa Claus. We apologize for the misuse of
the photograph.

In an Invisible Painting the
difference betweea tone and color within a canvas is so slight
that at first it appears homogeneous. The eye must adjust to
gradually perceive the depth of
what is, initially, an invisible
distinction.
The creators of Optical Paintings realize the discrepencies between physical fact and psychic
effect. They have concluded that
no color or shape haa an individual identity that cannot be
changed or altered by the elements that surround it.
If an artist is interested In
Causing the activation of vision

in the simplest manner he may
choose to work with Black and
White. Black and White provides a medium where sequential
changes in the spacing of shapes
cause to merge granting impressions of pulseatian and intensity.
Often the eye is presented with
such amazing visual energy that
it hallucinates color.
Moire Patterns are created by
calendering two rolls of silk face
to face placing one set of lines
on another in an off-parallel relationship. Reliefs and Construction are paintings, doubled
or squared.
Optical Art has begun a new
phase in art but brings with it
a host of new questions. William
Seitz, curator of the Museum of
Modern Art asks; "Can such
works, that refer to nothing outside themselves, replace with
psychic effectiveness the content
that has been abandoned?"
Clearly the answer lies not only
in a responsive eye but in a responsive mind as well.

MITRE is chief technical advisor and systems engineer to the Air
Force Electronic Systems Division of the Air Force Systems
Command. In this capacity, we design and develop such global,
computer-based systems as the NORAD Combat Operations
Center and the Back-Up Interceptor Control System. Other commitments: development of a future air traffic control system and
supporting the Defense Communications Agency in the development of the National Military Command System;
For the young systems engineer, this is uniquely rewarding work.
You associate with the top men in your field. You work in an
atmosphere that allows you to extend your capabilities professionally and academically.
At MITRE, men trained in single disciplines are encouraged to
grow beyond their original fields of interest. Systems designers
learn to work from an increasingly broad base.
You may work in such diverse areas as information theory, computer design, display techniques and propagation. You may
analyze. You may synthesize. You may deal with systems or individual components. At the highest levels, you may have to consider political, economic and social factors ... as well as the available and predictable technology.
Requirements: M.S., or Ph.D. in these disciplines — electronics,
physics, mathematics. MITRE is located in pleasant, suburban
Boston and also has facilities in Washington, D. C., Colorado
Springs and Florida. If an interview will be inconvenient, inquiries
may be directed in confidence to College Relations Coordinator,
The MITRE Corporation, Box 208, Dept. CN8, Bedford, Mass.

Prof. Refuses

Dr. Owen M. Phillips. a professor in the department of
mechanics at Hopkins, recently
refused to accept an award offered to him by the Maryland
Academy of Sciences. He refused a "distinguished young
scientist award" on the grounds
that the work of a scientist "is
reward enough in itself."
Dr. Phillips, a 34-year-old professor of Geophysical Mechanics
and a member of the faculty at
Hopkins since 1956, said that
he was "most grateful" for the
honor, but in a letter to the
academy wrote that he believed
"most sincerely that the value
of a scientist's work lies in his
contributions to our understanding of the world about us and in
the enlargement of this understanding in society and that the
doing of these things is reward
enough in itself. Though this
award may be intended as a recognition of my work in this
direction, I do not desire personal honors." Dr. Phillips then
requested to decline the award.
Dr. Phillips, a native of
Australia, came to Hopkins from
Cambridge University in England. He has published thirtyfive papers and is noted for his
work on waves and turbulence
in fluids.
Dr. George Benton, the chairman of the mechanics department, nominated Dr Phillips for
the award
without Phillip's
knowledge Dr Benton, corninentin.g on Dr Phillips action,
called Phillips "a tremendously
capable person" and a scientist
of "very broad gauge," and said
that the action was consistent
with Dr Phillips' modesty"

Insanity becomes their effective
means of compensation for the
deficiencies of the prison camp.
One character envisions his pet
chickens as children, one has
Illusions that his wife is with
him, and so on.
In the camp the usual stratification by military rank is broken
down — the artificial statuses
are destroyed and each character
is rewarded according to his
ability to survive. In one case
the characters steal from the
camp rations, but they are
caught by the provost and dismissed from their duties in
charge of the camp food.
King survives the ordeal best
of all—he is able to convert
goods into money and money
into food. He sells the jewelry
and possessions of the soldiers
to the Japanese for as much as
he can get, then keeps his commission. King has his followers
steal for him then sells the
goods to the Japanese, and as a
result the others starve while
King eats and dresses well. By
his own ingenuity he develops a
scheme to provide food for the
officers and money for himself.
King is the king of the camp—
his relationship with others is
based upon give and take. He
pays his followers for working
for him—and in return they do
favors for him. Only once does
King show any compassion for
his fellow prisoners—when he
acquires the sulfanimide to cure
Marlow from Gangreen.
When the war comes to an end
the old artificial order is reestablished and King is forced
to accept the usual commands
of his military superiors. He renounces his friendship with
Marlow and claims that it was
no more than the give and take

relationship that he had effectA

figure in relation to his society—
he is an idealist, and is able to
express compassion for other
human beings. But it is impossible for him to succeed within
society, because of these characteristics.
Society turns King into
tragic hero, defines Marlow as
tragic being, and in its own
terms sets the provost. as the
model to emulate. All this, of
course, is not nice.

Swordsmen Win In Opener
By BARON WORMSER
Coach Dick Oles' varsity fencing team started to key on a
winning season early by opening
with a 14-13 scrimmage win over
Virginia Military Institute Friday.
Helping to turn the trick
against the Cadets were Walt
Rosett, Bernie Tauflk, and Steve
Mohr, all of whom pasted 2-0
*cores.
As usual the fencers will be
handicapped by graduation losses
and inexperience. The swordsmen have lost sabre ace Sherm
ireichman and North Atlantic
epee champ Bob Kirby but in the
eoach's words, "Rather than give
long sad story of whom we
iost I'd rather just work with
what we have here."
Each year the Jays have been
able to bounce right back as last
year they finished third in the
Middle Atlantic Conference and

r

captured the conference diadem
in 1963.
Epee Strong
The fencers' strong point figures to be epee, led by co-captain
Walt Rosett, who is defending
epee champion. Randy Perrine
will fence number two position
while the third slot is up for
grabs. Also figuring to be the
fencers' forte is foil spearheaded
by co-captain and third place
Mid-Atlantic medalist Jeremy
Lam. Backing up Lain will be
Larry Perkins and a yet to be
named third man.

and build up. Commenting on
the saber team, Coach Oles stated
that he hopes it will be able to
pick up on experience.

Looking over the schedule, the
coach said that the Jays should
have a good crack at Lehigh,
Haverford Muhlenberg and Lafayette while Stevens and Temple
figure to be very close. As to
a win over Penn—"forget it."

now until January 7 when they
face the Baltimore Fencing Club
at Homewood.

the team's opener, a 71-69 victory over Franklin and Marshall,
Truitt, Hitchner and Fein hit
for 26, 20, and 11 points respectively.
Hitchner Tough
Freshman coach Gary Barrette,
who scouted Swarthmore, reports
that it uses a 2-1-2 offense with
Hitchner playing a low post and
carrying the brunt of the offensive load. Barrette was high in
his praise of the 6-3 junior, saying that he drives very well for
a pivot man, has a fine jump
shot, and is very tough off the
boards.
Defensively, the Garnets are
basically a man-to-man club
which can fast break and handle
a wide open style of play very
well.
Wednesday's Action
In this respect, Swarthmore is
much like the Jays' opponent of
last Wednesday, Catholic University, one of the toughest adversaries on the Homewood club's
schedule. Catholic U. recently
pushed small college cage power
Mount St. Mary's into overtime
before bowing, which pretty
much tells the tale regarding its
capabilities.
